body:
Best remedy is to stop producing conflicts, or just ignore the files which are causing them, as you clearly have something on both ends constantly modifying the files, hence causing conflicts.

Yes, we should probably add some limits on how many conflicts we keep.
As for BTSync, it's closed source, so there is nothing to copy from.

You can never stop producing conflicts if you, for instance, sync a browser profile folder. BTSync is closed source, but Sync as used by Mozilla firefox is not, they're doing quite well for me, syncing always the newest everywhere, without losing things. Ask around there, or better yet, get them involved, they're smart guys. (I'll try and help with that.)

Mozilla profiles contains SQLite write ahead logs (*.wal, *.shm) which need to be ignored, as they are not necessary to sync the profile itself and can change a few hundred times a second (hence the conflicts).

Because Mozilla Sync as written by Mozilla and is meant to sync Mozilla profiles, it knows perfectly well which files do not need to be synced, and simply does not sync them. Furthermore, I have high doubts that it's a file based solution, given it's inside Firefox, it probably just gets the information straight out of it, without having to look at the disk to start with.

I don't think we need any help, as we know exactly what's happening, I think users need to be aware that shoving everything into a generic sync solution is not the answer, some things should simply not be synced, or if they are, the user should understand what's the underlying file structure that he's syncing, and to exclude files which are not necessary and cause issues.

Regardless, the point you've raised is still valid, we should probably define a number of maximum conflicts we keep for each file, hence why this is still open.

@jult as Audrius has said - there might be a solution, but especially with things like browser profiles that are prone to be used at more than one location - you normally don't want to use a generic sync solution for that, as depending on file format it will fail or if accessed written to at the same time, can also easily produce conflicts. This is also not limited to Mozilla.

No, I was just giving the mozilla profile as an obvious example. For me almost every folder I've synced has too many (and way too old) _sync-conflict_ files in them. Especially their age should be a sign of them not having to be there. By now I've created a separate script that kills them if they're 2 days old (or older).

issue.title: disable sync-conflict generation on specific folders (enh)

labels.name: frozen-due-to-age
labels.description: Issues closed and untouched for a long time, together with being locked for discussion

issue.body:
Hello,

Is there a way to disable sync-conflict file generation for specific folders? 

Read https://github.com/syncthing/syncthing/issues/2282, think this is a slightly different enhancement. 

Use case is switching branches in a git directory, causing conflicts.

body: Still, it makes me wonder why such files have been generated in the first place. I never use more than one machine at a time, so the newest files are only generated where I'm at. Why the conflicts? The machine I'm using creates new or updated files, they should be synced with my NAS, and nothing on that NAS is using them, so they're just there. How do the conflicts appear?
The fact that they appear means that its happening. As I said, your are probably syncing memory mapped files.

I have just had to deal with the same issue - and as some of the posts above mention, this sometimes happens even when the files are clearly only changed on one side of the sync. In my case I had setup sync from a Windows desktop to a Linux server - and they are *only* ever changed on the Windows desktop - never on the Linux server. The desktop is set in master/send only mode. In my case it turned out that the reason why the conflict files were being created was because the desktop computer did not have its time synced with the Internet/NTP, and the clock was slow. I suppose this made the files coming from the desktop to the Linux server look modified, but at the same time older than the ones on the Linux server - which forced Syncthing to conclude the files must have been modified in both places.

I thought I would mention it here in case others are experiencing a similar issue.

@xj25vm If your clocks were out of sync, then that's almost certainly what was happening, and there's not anything that Syncthing can do about that.  It's well beyond the scope of Syncthing to manage the system's clock, and pretty much any other file sync software chokes when the clocks are out of sync.

I may take the time to add something about this to the documentation later.

@Ferroin Thank you for your reply. I wasn't suggesting that Syncthing should try to make up for this - just thought I would add a note here in case it helps others.

However, I'm afraid I have spoken too soon - as Syncthing is continuing to create conflict files although the clocks are now correct on both sides. I wonder what could be causing Syncthing to think that files on the Linux server - which are never changed by any human or software - are in conflict with the files on the desktop machine?

Is the content actually different? People always assume files are the same and nobody is modifying them, but crazy things happen, applications keep modifying mp3's increasing play count id tags, image indexing software keeps updating image metadata etc, so I wouldn't be so sure.

It shouldn't. This a Sage Accounts installation - with the back-end on the Windows desktop machine - and I use Syncthing to shift data to the Linux server - to include it later in the nightly backup. There is nothing on the server which can change the files - at least I can't think of anything.
Hence why I suggest you check the content for differences.
Would I be best doing that with checksums - or with diff maybe?
